Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Situation2: The polls close for good tonight, and this moment is the voter’s sole opportunity to present the mandated ID.
Story: I glance at the clock on my monitor, the digital numbers glowing 5:30 p.m. My shift as a telemarketer is supposed to end at six, but today the call volume is unusually light. My supervisor mentioned we could take our breaks flexibly, as long as we don’t abuse the privilege. I’ve been eyeing my wallet all day, double-checking that my ID is inside. The polling station closes at seven, and this is my only chance to vote. If I leave now, I’ll make it in time, but technically, my break isn’t scheduled for another half hour. I know the company expects me to stick to my hours, but the polls won’t wait. My heart pounds as I weigh the responsibility of my job against my right—and duty—to vote. I imagine my supervisor’s disappointment if I leave early, but I also picture the locked doors of the polling station if I wait too long. The pressure builds in my chest, torn between being a reliable employee and a responsible citizen, as the minutes tick by.
